questions.stem: What is the basic unit of all living things?

mcqOptions.text: Cell
mcqOptions.feedback: Correct! The cell is the basic unit of all living things. Every organism is made up of one or more cells.

mcqOptions.text: Atom
mcqOptions.feedback: Atoms are the basic units of matter, not living things. Cells are made up of many atoms working together.

mcqOptions.text: Tissue
mcqOptions.feedback: Tissues are groups of cells working together. The cell is smaller and more basic than tissue.

mcqOptions.text: Organ
mcqOptions.feedback: Organs are made up of different tissues. Cells are the most basic unit of living things.

questions.solution:
The answer is **cell**.

A **cell** is the **basic unit of life** - it is the smallest structure that can carry out all the processes needed for life. All living organisms, from tiny bacteria to giant whales, are made up of one or more cells.

This is a fundamental principle of **cell theory**: all living things are made of cells. Just as bricks are the basic building blocks of a house, cells are the building blocks of all living organisms.

hints.text: Think about what scientists mean by 'building blocks of life'. What is the smallest living structure?
Cell theory states that all living things are made of these tiny structures that can carry out life processes.
The word rhymes with 'bell' and starts with the letter 'C'. It's what you see when you look through a microscope at living tissue.

pedagogy.purpose: Establish foundational vocabulary - the term 'cell' as basic unit of life

questions.stem: Which tool do scientists use to see cells?

mcqOptions.text: Telescope
mcqOptions.feedback: Telescopes are used to see distant objects in space, not tiny cells. You need a different tool to see very small things.

mcqOptions.text: Microscope
mcqOptions.feedback: Correct! A microscope is used to magnify tiny objects like cells so we can see them. Most cells are too small to see with just our eyes.

mcqOptions.text: Magnifying glass
mcqOptions.feedback: While a magnifying glass can make things bigger, it doesn't magnify enough to see individual cells. You need more powerful magnification.

mcqOptions.text: Stethoscope
mcqOptions.feedback: A stethoscope is used to listen to sounds inside the body, like heartbeats. It doesn't help you see cells.

questions.solution:
The answer is **microscope**.

A **microscope** is a scientific tool that uses lenses to **magnify** very small objects, making them appear much larger. Most cells are incredibly tiny - typically between 0.01 to 0.1 millimetres - which is far too small to see with our naked eyes.

Microscopes allow scientists to study the structure and behaviour of cells by magnifying them hundreds or even thousands of times. The discovery of cells was only possible after the invention of the microscope in the 1600s.

hints.text: Think about what equipment you would find in a science laboratory for looking at very small things.
The name of this tool contains the word 'micro', which means very small.
This tool has lenses that magnify objects so you can see tiny structures like cells. It sits on a lab bench and you look through an eyepiece.

pedagogy.purpose: Introduce essential equipment vocabulary for cell study

questions.stem: Which of the following is a living organism?

mcqOptions.text: A rock
mcqOptions.feedback: A rock is not living - it doesn't grow, reproduce, or respond to its environment. Rocks are made of minerals, not cells.

mcqOptions.text: A bacteria
mcqOptions.feedback: Correct! A bacteria is a living organism. Even though it's made of just one cell, it can grow, reproduce, and carry out all life processes.

mcqOptions.text: Water
mcqOptions.feedback: Water is not living - it's a chemical compound. Living things need water, but water itself is not an organism.

mcqOptions.text: A plastic bottle
mcqOptions.feedback: A plastic bottle is not living. It's a manufactured object made from chemicals, not cells. It cannot grow or reproduce.

questions.solution:
The answer is **a bacteria**.

A **bacteria** is a **living organism** because it is made of at least one cell and can carry out all the processes of life: it can grow, reproduce, respond to its environment, and obtain energy from its surroundings.

Even though bacteria are single-celled organisms (made of just one cell), they are fully alive. This demonstrates that **all living things are made of cells** - whether it's one cell (like bacteria) or trillions of cells (like humans).

Rocks, water, and plastic bottles are not made of cells, so they are not living organisms.

hints.text: Remember that all living things are made of cells. Which option contains cells?
Think about what characteristics define life: growth, reproduction, response to environment. Which option can do these things?
Look for the option that is a tiny microscopic creature made of at least one cell.

pedagogy.purpose: Apply understanding that living things are made of cells

questions.stem: Cell theory states that all living things are made of:

mcqOptions.text: Atoms only
mcqOptions.feedback: While cells are made of atoms, cell theory specifically refers to cells as the basic unit of life, not atoms.

mcqOptions.text: One or more cells
mcqOptions.feedback: Correct! Cell theory states that all living things are made of one or more cells. This is one of the three main principles of cell theory.

mcqOptions.text: Exactly one cell
mcqOptions.feedback: Some organisms (like bacteria) are made of one cell, but many organisms (like humans) are made of trillions of cells. Cell theory says 'one or more' cells.

mcqOptions.text: Only multicellular structures
mcqOptions.feedback: This would exclude single-celled organisms like bacteria. Cell theory includes both single-celled and multicellular organisms.

questions.solution:
The answer is **one or more cells**.

**Cell theory** is a fundamental principle in biology that states:
1. All living things are made of **one or more cells**
2. The cell is the basic unit of life
3. All cells come from pre-existing cells

This means that some organisms (like bacteria and amoebas) are made of just **one cell** (unicellular), while others (like plants, animals, and fungi) are made of **many cells** (multicellular). Both types are living organisms because they are made of cells.

This principle helps us understand that cells are the foundation of all life on Earth.

hints.text: Think about what you learned about cell theory. What does it say about how many cells living things have?
Some organisms like bacteria have just one cell, while humans have trillions. What phrase covers both possibilities?
The answer includes the number 'one' and continues with a phrase that means 'or many more'.

pedagogy.purpose: Introduce first principle of cell theory explicitly

questions.stem: You observe cheek cells under a microscope. You see billions of cells lining just the inside of your mouth. What does this observation tell you about your body?

mcqOptions.text: Your body is made of many cells working together
mcqOptions.feedback: Correct! The fact that you can see billions of cells in just one small area shows that your entire body is made of trillions of cells. You are a multicellular organism.

mcqOptions.text: Your body is made of only one large cell
mcqOptions.feedback: If you can see many separate cells under the microscope, your body must be made of many cells, not just one.

mcqOptions.text: Your body has no cells in other parts
mcqOptions.feedback: If you have billions of cells just in your mouth, other parts of your body also have cells. All parts of living organisms are made of cells.

mcqOptions.text: Only your mouth contains cells
mcqOptions.feedback: All parts of your body are made of cells, not just your mouth. This is what cell theory tells us.

questions.solution:
The answer is **your body is made of many cells working together**.

When you observe cheek cells under a microscope, you can see billions of individual cells in just a small area of your mouth lining. This demonstrates that your body is a **multicellular organism** - an organism made of many cells.

In fact, the human body contains approximately **37 trillion cells**! Different types of cells work together to carry out all the functions needed for life. The cheek cells you observe are just one type of cell in your body.

This observation confirms **cell theory**: all living things (including humans) are made of one or more cells.

hints.text: Think about what it means if you can see many separate cells under the microscope. What does this tell you about how your body is built?
If there are billions of cells in just your mouth, what does that suggest about the rest of your body?
Look for the answer that describes your body as being made of multiple cells that work together.

pedagogy.purpose: Connect cell theory to real-world observation - cheek cells under microscope (p5)

questions.stem: List three examples of living organisms. For each one, state whether it is made of one cell or many cells.
questions.solution:
Here are three examples of living organisms:

1. **Bacteria** - made of **one cell** (unicellular). Bacteria are microscopic organisms that can carry out all life processes in a single cell.

2. **Human** - made of **many cells** (multicellular). The human body contains approximately 37 trillion cells of different types.

3. **Plant (e.g., a tree)** - made of **many cells** (multicellular). Plants have millions or billions of cells that work together to carry out photosynthesis, growth, and reproduction.

(Other acceptable examples include: amoeba [one cell], fungus [many cells], dog [many cells], algae [can be one or many cells], yeast [one cell])

This demonstrates **cell theory**: all living things are made of one or more cells, but the number of cells varies widely between different organisms.

hints.text: Think about different types of living things you've learned about - tiny bacteria, animals, plants. Are they all made the same way?
Remember that some organisms are made of just one cell (like bacteria), while others (like humans and trees) are made of many cells working together.
Choose three organisms from different groups: perhaps a microscopic organism, an animal, and a plant. State clearly if each is 'one cell' or 'many cells'.

pedagogy.purpose: Apply understanding of unicellular vs multicellular organisms

questions.stem: What is the term used to describe an organism made of many cells?

mcqOptions.text: Unicellular
mcqOptions.feedback: Unicellular means made of ONE cell (uni = one). An organism made of many cells has a different name.

mcqOptions.text: Multicellular
mcqOptions.feedback: Correct! Multicellular means made of MANY cells (multi = many). Humans, plants, and animals are all multicellular organisms.

mcqOptions.text: Microscopic
mcqOptions.feedback: Microscopic means very small and needing a microscope to see. This doesn't describe how many cells an organism has.

mcqOptions.text: Cellular
mcqOptions.feedback: Cellular just means 'relating to cells', but doesn't specify whether there is one cell or many cells.

questions.solution:
The answer is **multicellular**.

The prefix **'multi-'** means 'many', so **multicellular** literally means 'made of many cells'. Multicellular organisms have many cells that work together and often specialize to perform different functions.

Examples of multicellular organisms include:
- Humans (about 37 trillion cells)
- Trees (billions of cells)
- Dogs, cats, birds (millions to trillions of cells)
- Fungi like mushrooms (millions of cells)

In contrast, **unicellular** organisms (prefix 'uni-' means 'one') are made of just a single cell, like bacteria and amoebas.

Both unicellular and multicellular organisms follow **cell theory**: they are all made of one or more cells.

hints.text: Think about prefixes. 'Uni-' means one, so what prefix might mean 'many'?
The prefix 'multi-' means many or multiple. Combine this with the word 'cellular'.
The answer starts with 'multi-' and ends with 'cellular'. It means 'made of many cells'.

pedagogy.purpose: Introduce key vocabulary term for organisms made of many cells

questions.stem: What does the term 'magnification' mean when using a microscope?

mcqOptions.text: How many cells you can see at once
mcqOptions.feedback: Magnification is about how much bigger things appear, not how many things you can see.

mcqOptions.text: How much larger an object appears compared to its actual size
mcqOptions.feedback: Correct! Magnification tells you how many times bigger an object appears when viewed through the microscope compared to its real size. For example, 100× magnification means the object looks 100 times bigger.

mcqOptions.text: The distance between the microscope and the object
mcqOptions.feedback: This describes the working distance, not magnification. Magnification is about how much bigger things appear.

mcqOptions.text: How bright the light is under the microscope
mcqOptions.feedback: Light brightness is about illumination, not magnification. Magnification refers to size increase.

questions.solution:
The answer is **how much larger an object appears compared to its actual size**.

**Magnification** is the amount by which an object is enlarged when viewed through a microscope. It is expressed as a number followed by the '×' symbol (times).

For example:
- **100× magnification** means the object appears 100 times larger than its actual size
- **400× magnification** means the object appears 400 times larger than its actual size

Magnification is calculated by multiplying the power of the eyepiece lens by the power of the objective lens. High magnification is essential for viewing cells, which are typically too small to see with the naked eye.

Without magnification, we would never have discovered cells or understood cell theory!

hints.text: Think about what happens when you look through a microscope. Do things appear bigger or smaller?
The word 'magnify' means to make something appear larger. Magnification tells you HOW MUCH larger.
Look for the answer that talks about comparing the apparent size (how big it looks) with the actual size (how big it really is).

pedagogy.purpose: Define key microscopy vocabulary term

questions.stem: According to cell theory, where do new cells come from?

mcqOptions.text: They are created from non-living matter
mcqOptions.feedback: Cell theory states that cells cannot be created from non-living matter. All cells must come from other living cells.

mcqOptions.text: They grow spontaneously from nutrients
mcqOptions.feedback: Cells don't appear spontaneously from nutrients. They must come from pre-existing cells through cell division.

mcqOptions.text: Pre-existing cells
mcqOptions.feedback: Correct! Cell theory states that all cells come from pre-existing cells through a process called cell division. One cell divides to create two new cells.

mcqOptions.text: Different types of organisms
mcqOptions.feedback: Cells don't come from different organisms. They come from other cells of the same type through cell division.

questions.solution:
The answer is **pre-existing cells**.

One of the three key principles of **cell theory** states that **all cells come from pre-existing cells**. This means that:
- New cells are created when existing cells divide in two (a process called **cell division**)
- Cells cannot spontaneously appear from non-living matter
- Living things produce more living things

This principle was established in the mid-1800s and disproved the earlier idea of 'spontaneous generation' (the belief that living things could arise from non-living matter).

For example, when you grow, your body creates new cells through the division of existing cells. A single cell divides to become two cells, those two divide to become four, and so on.

hints.text: Think about the three principles of cell theory. One of them describes where new cells come from.
Cell theory states that cells cannot appear from nowhere. They must come from something that already exists. What?
New cells are created when existing cells divide. Look for the answer that mentions cells that already exist.

pedagogy.purpose: Introduce third principle of cell theory - cells from pre-existing cells

questions.stem: State the three main principles of cell theory.
questions.solution:
The three main principles of **cell theory** are:

1. **All living things are made of one or more cells.**
   - This means every organism, from tiny bacteria to giant whales, is made of cells.

2. **The cell is the basic unit of life.**
   - Cells are the smallest structures that can carry out all the processes needed for life.

3. **All cells come from pre-existing cells.**
   - New cells are created when existing cells divide. Cells cannot appear spontaneously from non-living matter.

These three principles form the foundation of our understanding of life and biology. Cell theory was developed in the 1800s by scientists like Matthias Schleiden, Theodor Schwann, and Rudolf Virchow, and it remains one of the most important theories in biology today.

hints.text: Think about what you've learned about cells being the building blocks of life, and where new cells come from.
Cell theory describes: (1) what living things are made of, (2) what the basic unit of life is, and (3) where new cells come from.
The three principles talk about: (1) all living things and cells, (2) cells as the basic unit, and (3) cells coming from pre-existing cells.

pedagogy.purpose: Consolidate all three principles of cell theory together

questions.stem: All cells contain three basic structures. Which of the following is NOT one of these three basic structures?

mcqOptions.text: Cell membrane
mcqOptions.feedback: The cell membrane IS one of the three basic structures found in all cells. It surrounds the cell and controls what enters and exits.

mcqOptions.text: Cytoplasm
mcqOptions.feedback: Cytoplasm IS one of the three basic structures found in all cells. It's the jelly-like substance inside the cell where chemical reactions occur.

mcqOptions.text: Genetic material (DNA)
mcqOptions.feedback: Genetic material (DNA) IS one of the three basic structures found in all cells. It contains the instructions for the cell.

mcqOptions.text: Chloroplast
mcqOptions.feedback: Correct! Chloroplasts are NOT found in all cells. They are only found in plant cells and some other organisms that carry out photosynthesis. The three structures ALL cells have are: cell membrane, cytoplasm, and genetic material (DNA).

questions.solution:
The answer is **chloroplast**.

**All cells** - whether animal, plant, bacteria, or fungi - contain three basic structures:
1. **Cell membrane** - the outer boundary that controls what enters and leaves the cell
2. **Cytoplasm** - the jelly-like substance inside the cell where chemical reactions occur
3. **Genetic material (DNA)** - the instructions that control how the cell functions

**Chloroplasts** are NOT found in all cells. They are specialized structures found only in **plant cells** and some other photosynthetic organisms. Chloroplasts contain chlorophyll and are responsible for photosynthesis (making food from sunlight).

Animal cells, fungi, and bacteria do NOT have chloroplasts because they don't carry out photosynthesis.

hints.text: Think about what structures ALL cells must have to survive. What do you find in animal cells, plant cells, and bacterial cells?
Consider which structure is only found in cells that make their own food from sunlight. Do animal cells have this structure?
Three structures (cell membrane, cytoplasm, DNA) are found in ALL cells. One structure is only in plant cells.

pedagogy.purpose: Introduce the three universal cell structures (c2)

questions.stem: What is the function of the cell membrane?

mcqOptions.text: To store genetic information
mcqOptions.feedback: Genetic information (DNA) is stored in the nucleus (in plant and animal cells) or in the cytoplasm (in bacteria), not in the cell membrane.

mcqOptions.text: To control what enters and exits the cell
mcqOptions.feedback: Correct! The cell membrane acts as a barrier and controls what substances can enter and leave the cell. It's like a security guard, letting useful substances in and keeping harmful substances out.

mcqOptions.text: To produce energy for the cell
mcqOptions.feedback: Energy is produced in mitochondria (in plant and animal cells), not in the cell membrane.

mcqOptions.text: To carry out photosynthesis
mcqOptions.feedback: Photosynthesis occurs in chloroplasts (in plant cells), not in the cell membrane.

questions.solution:
The answer is **to control what enters and exits the cell**.

The **cell membrane** is a thin, flexible barrier that surrounds all cells. Its main function is to **control what substances can enter and leave the cell**. Think of it as a security checkpoint:

- It lets **useful substances** (like nutrients, water, and oxygen) enter the cell
- It lets **waste products** leave the cell
- It keeps **harmful substances** out of the cell

This selective control is essential for the cell's survival. Without the cell membrane, the cell couldn't maintain the right internal conditions, and harmful substances could damage the cell.

The cell membrane is one of the **three basic structures found in all cells** (along with cytoplasm and genetic material).

hints.text: Think about the cell membrane's position - it surrounds the outside of the cell. What might its job be?
The cell membrane acts like a barrier or security guard. What does a barrier do?
Look for the answer that mentions controlling movement of substances in and out of the cell.

pedagogy.purpose: Define function of first universal structure - cell membrane

questions.stem: Why was the discovery of cells only possible after the invention of the microscope?

mcqOptions.text: Cells didn't exist before microscopes were invented
mcqOptions.feedback: Cells have always existed! Cell theory tells us that all cells come from pre-existing cells, so cells existed long before humans invented microscopes.

mcqOptions.text: Most cells are too small to see with the naked eye
mcqOptions.feedback: Correct! Most cells are microscopic (typically 0.01-0.1 mm), which means they're too small to see without magnification. The microscope made cells visible for the first time.

mcqOptions.text: Cells are invisible unless you use a microscope
mcqOptions.feedback: Cells aren't invisible - they're just very small. A few cells (like some egg cells) are large enough to see without a microscope.

mcqOptions.text: Scientists needed microscopes to create cells
mcqOptions.feedback: Scientists don't create cells. According to cell theory, all cells come from pre-existing cells through cell division.

questions.solution:
The answer is **most cells are too small to see with the naked eye**.

The discovery of cells was only possible after the microscope was invented because **most cells are microscopic** - they are far too small to see without magnification. A typical cell is between **0.01 to 0.1 millimetres** in size, which is much smaller than the human eye can detect.

Historical timeline:
- **1665**: Robert Hooke invented one of the first microscopes and discovered cells by looking at cork (dead plant tissue)
- **1670s**: Antoni van Leeuwenhoek used microscopes to observe living cells for the first time
- **1830s-1850s**: Scientists developed cell theory after observing many different types of cells

Without the **magnification** provided by microscopes, we would never have known that cells exist or understood that they are the basic building blocks of all living things.

hints.text: Think about what property of cells would make them impossible to discover without special equipment.
Consider the size of cells. Can you see them with just your eyes? What do you need to see very small things?
Cells are microscopic - they're too small to see without magnification. Look for the answer about size.

pedagogy.purpose: Connect cell theory, microscopy, and cell size through reasoning

questions.stem: What is cytoplasm?

mcqOptions.text: The outer boundary of the cell
mcqOptions.feedback: The outer boundary is the cell membrane, not cytoplasm. Cytoplasm is found inside the cell.

mcqOptions.text: The jelly-like substance inside the cell where chemical reactions occur
mcqOptions.feedback: Correct! Cytoplasm is the jelly-like fluid that fills the cell. It contains water, nutrients, and dissolved substances, and it's where many important chemical reactions take place.

mcqOptions.text: The genetic material that controls the cell
mcqOptions.feedback: The genetic material (DNA) is separate from cytoplasm, though DNA is suspended in cytoplasm in some cells.

mcqOptions.text: The structure that produces energy
mcqOptions.feedback: Energy is produced in mitochondria (in plant and animal cells), not in the cytoplasm itself, though mitochondria are found within the cytoplasm.

questions.solution:
The answer is **the jelly-like substance inside the cell where chemical reactions occur**.

**Cytoplasm** is the gel-like fluid that fills the interior of all cells. It has several important characteristics:

- It's made mostly of **water** (about 70-80%)
- It contains **dissolved nutrients, salts, and proteins**
- It provides a medium for **chemical reactions** that keep the cell alive
- Other cell structures (like organelles) are suspended in the cytoplasm

Think of cytoplasm like the water in a swimming pool - the pool has boundaries (the cell membrane), and various objects (cell structures) float or sit in the water, with chemical processes happening throughout.

Cytoplasm is one of the **three basic structures found in all cells** (along with cell membrane and genetic material).

hints.text: Think about what fills the space inside a cell. What substance surrounds all the cell structures?
The word 'cyto-' means cell and '-plasm' means formed substance. It's the substance that fills the cell.
Look for the answer that describes a jelly-like or fluid substance inside the cell where reactions happen.

pedagogy.purpose: Define function of second universal structure - cytoplasm

questions.stem:
You are looking at a sample under a microscope at 40× magnification and you can barely see the cells. You switch to 400× magnification.

Describe what happens to your view of the cells when you increase the magnification.
questions.solution:
When you increase the magnification from **40×** to **400×**, several changes occur:

1. **The cells appear much larger** - they look 10 times bigger than before (400 ÷ 40 = 10)

2. **You can see more detail** - structures within the cells that were too small to see at 40× magnification become visible at 400× magnification

3. **You can see fewer cells at once** - the field of view becomes narrower, so you see a smaller area of the sample but with much more detail

4. **The cells are easier to study** - at higher magnification, you can examine cell structures like the cell membrane, cytoplasm, and nucleus more clearly

This demonstrates why microscopes are essential for cell biology - they provide the **magnification** needed to see and study the tiny structures that make up living organisms.

hints.text: Think about what 'magnification' means - how does increasing it from 40× to 400× affect what you see?
At higher magnification, objects appear larger. How many times larger will the cells appear? What other changes might happen to your view?
Consider: (1) how much bigger the cells look, (2) how much detail you can see, and (3) how much of the sample is visible at once.

pedagogy.purpose: Apply understanding of magnification to practical microscopy scenario

questions.stem: What is the role of genetic material (DNA) in a cell?

mcqOptions.text: To control what enters and exits the cell
mcqOptions.feedback: This is the role of the cell membrane, not DNA. DNA has a different function.

mcqOptions.text: To provide structure and support to the cell
mcqOptions.feedback: While some cell structures provide support, DNA's main role is not structural. Think about what information DNA contains.

mcqOptions.text: To contain the instructions that control how the cell functions
mcqOptions.feedback: Correct! DNA (genetic material) contains all the instructions the cell needs to function, grow, and reproduce. It's like an instruction manual for the cell.

mcqOptions.text: To produce energy for the cell
mcqOptions.feedback: Energy production occurs in mitochondria (in plant and animal cells), not in the DNA.

questions.solution:
The answer is **to contain the instructions that control how the cell functions**.

**DNA** (deoxyribonucleic acid) is the **genetic material** found in all cells. Its role is to store and provide the **instructions** that control:
- How the cell functions day-to-day
- What proteins the cell makes
- How the cell grows and develops
- How the cell reproduces

Think of DNA as an **instruction manual** or **recipe book** for the cell. Just as a recipe tells you exactly how to make a cake, DNA tells the cell exactly how to carry out all its life processes.

DNA is one of the **three basic structures found in all cells** (along with cell membrane and cytoplasm). **Every living thing** - from bacteria to plants to animals - contains DNA. This shows that all life on Earth shares a common heritage.

hints.text: Think about what DNA is famous for. What information does it carry?
DNA is often called the 'instruction manual' or 'blueprint' of the cell. What does an instruction manual do?
Look for the answer that mentions instructions or information that tells the cell how to work.

pedagogy.purpose: Define function of third universal structure - genetic material (DNA)

questions.stem:
A student says: 'Some parts of my body, like my hair and fingernails, are not made of cells because they're not alive.'

Is this statement correct? Explain your answer.

mcqOptions.text: Yes, because hair and nails don't grow, so they can't be made of cells
mcqOptions.feedback: Hair and nails DO grow! They are produced by living cells at the root/base, even though the visible parts are made of dead cells.

mcqOptions.text: Yes, because hair and nails feel hard, so they must be made of something other than cells
mcqOptions.feedback: Being hard doesn't mean something isn't made of cells. Hair and nails are made of dead cells that have hardened.

mcqOptions.text: No, because hair and nails are made of dead cells that were once living cells
mcqOptions.feedback: Correct! Hair and fingernails are made of dead cells. These cells were once alive and produced by your body. Cell theory states that all parts of living organisms come from cells - even parts made of dead cells.

mcqOptions.text: No, because hair and nails are living tissues that need food and oxygen
mcqOptions.feedback: The visible parts of hair and nails are actually NOT living - they're made of dead cells. However, they are still made of cells, which is why the student's statement is incorrect.

questions.solution:
The statement is **incorrect**.

Hair and fingernails **are made of cells** - specifically, they are made of **dead cells**. Here's why:

1. Hair and nails are **produced by living cells** at their roots/base (hair follicles and nail beds)
2. As these cells are pushed outward, they die and harden, forming the hair shaft or fingernail we can see
3. The visible parts (hair and nails) are made of **dead cells**, but they are still cells

This addresses a common **misconception** (m4): some students think that non-living parts of organisms are not made of cells. However, **cell theory** tells us that **all living organisms are made of cells** - including the parts that are made of dead cells.

Other examples of dead cells in your body: the outer layer of your skin is made of dead skin cells that constantly flake off.

hints.text: Think about cell theory. Does it say that ALL parts of living organisms come from cells, or only some parts?
Consider where hair and nails come from. Are they produced by your body? If so, what are they made from?
Hair and nails are made of cells that have died. Dead cells are still cells. Look for the answer that explains this.

pedagogy.purpose: Address misconception m4: some living parts are not made of cells

questions.stem:
Complete the table below by describing the function of each basic cell structure:

| Cell Structure | Function |
|----------------|----------|
| Cell membrane | ? |
| Cytoplasm | ? |
| Genetic material (DNA) | ? |
questions.solution:
| Cell Structure | Function |
|----------------|----------|
| Cell membrane | **Controls what enters and exits the cell** (acts as a selective barrier) |
| Cytoplasm | **Jelly-like substance where chemical reactions occur** (provides medium for cell processes) |
| Genetic material (DNA) | **Contains instructions that control how the cell functions** (stores genetic information) |

These three structures are found in **all cells** - whether animal, plant, bacterial, or fungal. They represent the minimum requirements for a structure to be considered a living cell:

- **Cell membrane** provides boundary and control
- **Cytoplasm** provides space and medium for reactions
- **DNA** provides instructions and inheritance

Together, these structures enable cells to carry out all the processes needed for life.

hints.text: Think about what you've learned about each structure. What does each one do for the cell?
Cell membrane is the boundary (controls entry/exit), cytoplasm is the inside fluid (where reactions happen), and DNA contains information (instructions).
Use these key words: cell membrane = 'controls entry and exit', cytoplasm = 'where reactions occur', DNA = 'contains instructions'.

pedagogy.purpose: Consolidate understanding of three universal cell structures and functions

questions.stem: Which of the following statements about DNA is correct?

mcqOptions.text: Only animal cells contain DNA
mcqOptions.feedback: This is incorrect. ALL living things contain DNA - animals, plants, fungi, and bacteria all have genetic material.

mcqOptions.text: DNA is only found in plant cells and animal cells, not in bacteria
mcqOptions.feedback: Bacteria definitely contain DNA! They store it differently (not in a nucleus), but all living things have genetic material.

mcqOptions.text: All living things contain DNA
mcqOptions.feedback: Correct! DNA (genetic material) is found in ALL living cells. This is one of the three basic structures that all cells must have. Every living organism - animal, plant, fungus, or bacteria - contains DNA.

mcqOptions.text: Plants and fungi do not have DNA, only animals have DNA
mcqOptions.feedback: This is a common misconception (m11). Plants and fungi DO have DNA! All living things contain genetic material.

questions.solution:
The answer is **all living things contain DNA**.

**DNA** (genetic material) is one of the three basic structures found in **all cells**, regardless of the type of organism. This means:

- **Animal cells** contain DNA ✓
- **Plant cells** contain DNA ✓
- **Fungal cells** contain DNA ✓
- **Bacterial cells** contain DNA ✓

While the location and organization of DNA may differ between cell types (for example, animal and plant cells store DNA in a nucleus, while bacteria store DNA in their cytoplasm), **every living cell contains genetic material**.

This is fundamental to cell theory and demonstrates that all life on Earth shares a common origin. DNA is universal to life - it's what allows cells to function, reproduce, and pass on characteristics to offspring.

hints.text: Think about the three basic structures that ALL cells must have. Is DNA one of them?
Remember that DNA is the genetic material. Do plants reproduce and pass on traits? Do bacteria reproduce? What does this tell you?
DNA is found in all living cells - animal, plant, fungus, and bacteria. Look for the most inclusive answer.

pedagogy.purpose: Address misconception m11: only animals have DNA, and reinforce universality of DNA

questions.stem:
Explain why cell theory is considered one of the most important theories in biology. In your answer:
- State what cell theory tells us about living things
- Explain why this is important for understanding life
questions.solution:
**Cell theory** is one of the most important theories in biology because it provides the foundation for understanding all life on Earth.

**What cell theory tells us:**

Cell theory states three key principles:
1. All living things are made of one or more cells
2. The cell is the basic unit of life
3. All cells come from pre-existing cells

**Why this is important:**

- **Unifying principle**: Cell theory shows that ALL living organisms - from tiny bacteria to giant whales - share a common structure and origin. This demonstrates that all life is connected.

- **Understanding life processes**: By studying cells, we can understand how ALL living things function, grow, reproduce, and respond to their environment.

- **Medical advances**: Understanding cells has led to breakthroughs in medicine, including how diseases work, how to develop treatments, and how bodies heal.

- **Research foundation**: Cell theory guides all biological research - when we study life, we study cells.

Without cell theory, we wouldn't understand what makes something "alive" or how life continues from generation to generation. It's as fundamental to biology as atomic theory is to chemistry.

hints.text: Think about what you've learned about cell theory throughout this set. What are its main ideas, and why do they matter?
Consider: (1) What do the three principles of cell theory tell us? (2) How does understanding cells help us understand all living things?
Structure your answer: first state the three principles of cell theory, then explain why understanding that all life is made of cells is important for biology and medicine.

pedagogy.purpose: Synthesize Phase 1 learning - evaluate importance of cell theory as foundation of biology

questions.stem:
You get a small cut on your finger. Over the next few days, you notice the cut healing and closing up.

What must be happening to the cells at the cut site?

mcqOptions.text: Existing cells stretch to cover the gap
mcqOptions.feedback: Cells don't stretch like rubber bands. New cells need to be created to fill the gap.

mcqOptions.text: New cells are being produced to replace damaged ones
mcqOptions.feedback: Correct! The nucleus controls cell division, creating new skin cells that fill the gap. This is how all wounds heal - through the production of new cells.

mcqOptions.text: Blood cells transform into skin cells
mcqOptions.feedback: Blood cells cannot transform into skin cells. Each cell type has a specific function determined by its nucleus.

mcqOptions.text: The cut fills with liquid that hardens into new skin
mcqOptions.feedback: Healing requires actual cells to be produced, not just fluid. The nucleus in nearby cells controls this process.

questions.solution:
The answer is **B**.

**Wound healing at the cellular level:**

1. Cells near the cut receive signals that damage has occurred
2. The **nucleus** in these cells activates genes for cell division
3. Cells divide to produce **new daughter cells**
4. New cells migrate to the damaged area
5. These cells gradually **fill the gap**, closing the wound

This demonstrates the nucleus's role as the **control centre** - it contains DNA with instructions for making new cells. Without a functioning nucleus, cells cannot divide and wounds cannot heal.

This connects to phenomenon **p1** - observing healing in real life!

hints.content: Think about what the nucleus does. How do you get more cells?
The nucleus controls cell division. Healing requires new cells to replace damaged ones.

pedagogy.targetFeeling: This is how it works in real life!

questions.stem:
A student looks at onion skin cells under a microscope and sees rectangular cells with thick outer edges.

Which cell structure gives the onion cells their rectangular shape?

mcqOptions.text: Cell membrane
mcqOptions.feedback: The cell membrane is flexible and found in all cells. It doesn't create the rigid rectangular shape.

mcqOptions.text: Nucleus
mcqOptions.feedback: The nucleus is inside the cell and doesn't determine the outer shape.

mcqOptions.text: Cell wall
mcqOptions.feedback: Correct! The cell wall is rigid and provides structure to plant cells, giving them their distinctive rectangular shape. Animal cells lack cell walls, which is why they have irregular shapes.

mcqOptions.text: Cytoplasm
mcqOptions.feedback: Cytoplasm is the jelly-like substance inside cells. It doesn't provide rigid structure.

questions.solution:
The answer is **C**.

**Why onion cells are rectangular:**

Onion skin cells are **plant cells** with these structures:
- **Cell wall**: Rigid outer layer made of cellulose → provides **rectangular shape**
- **Cell membrane**: Thin layer just inside the cell wall → controls what enters/exits
- **Cytoplasm**: Jelly-like interior
- **Nucleus**: Control centre (sometimes hard to see in onion cells)

The thick edges you see under the microscope are the **cell walls**. These rigid structures:
- Stack neatly together like bricks
- Provide support and protection
- Give plants their firm structure

This connects to phenomenon **p6** - observing onion cells under a microscope!

hints.content: Which structure is unique to plant cells and provides rigid support?
Think about what makes plant cells different from animal cells. What gives them their box-like shape?

pedagogy.targetFeeling: This is how it works in real life!

questions.stem:
You examine two different cells under a microscope:

**Cell A:** Has a cell wall, large central vacuole, and chloroplasts
**Cell B:** Has a cell membrane, small vacuoles, and no cell wall

Identify which is a plant cell and which is an animal cell. Explain your reasoning using at least two cell structures.
questions.solution:
**Cell A is a plant cell**
**Cell B is an animal cell**

**Reasoning:**

**Three key differences identify them:**

1. **Cell wall**: Cell A has a cell wall, which is found ONLY in plant cells. The rigid cell wall provides structure and support. Animal cells have only a flexible cell membrane.

2. **Chloroplasts**: Cell A has chloroplasts, which contain chlorophyll for photosynthesis. Only plant cells have chloroplasts because only plants make their own food. Animal cells get energy by eating food.

3. **Vacuole size**: Cell A has a large central vacuole (stores water, nutrients, and waste). Animal cells (Cell B) have small vacuoles or none at all.

**Both cells share:** Cell membrane, cytoplasm, and nucleus (all cells have these basic structures).

The presence of a cell wall, chloroplasts, and large vacuole are **distinguishing features** of plant cells!

hints.content: Think about which structures are found ONLY in plant cells versus structures found in ALL cells.
Cell walls, chloroplasts, and large vacuoles are unique to plant cells. Which cell has these?

pedagogy.targetFeeling: This is how it works in real life!

questions.stem:
Leaves appear green in sunlight because they contain chloroplasts with chlorophyll.

In which plant cells would you NOT expect to find chloroplasts?

mcqOptions.text: Leaf cells on the top surface
mcqOptions.feedback: Upper leaf cells are exposed to sunlight and need chloroplasts for photosynthesis.

mcqOptions.text: Stem cells exposed to light
mcqOptions.feedback: Green stem cells contain chloroplasts and can photosynthesize.

mcqOptions.text: Root cells underground
mcqOptions.feedback: Correct! Root cells are underground where there's no light. Since photosynthesis requires light, chloroplasts would be useless in roots. Not all plant cells have chloroplasts!

mcqOptions.text: Guard cells around stomata
mcqOptions.feedback: Guard cells contain chloroplasts and use photosynthesis to help control stomata opening.

questions.solution:
The answer is **C**.

**This addresses misconception m5**: "All plant cells have chloroplasts"

**The reality:**

| Plant Part | Light Exposure | Has Chloroplasts? | Why? |
|------------|----------------|-------------------|------|
| Leaves | High | Yes ✓ | Main site of photosynthesis |
| Green stems | Moderate | Yes ✓ | Can photosynthesize |
| Roots | None (underground) | No ✗ | No light = no photosynthesis needed |
| Flower petals | Variable | Sometimes | Depends on colour and function |

**Key principle:** Chloroplasts are found only where **photosynthesis occurs**. Since photosynthesis requires **light**, cells in dark locations (like roots) don't need chloroplasts.

Root cells still have:
- Cell wall
- Cell membrane
- Nucleus
- Cytoplasm
- Large vacuole

But NO chloroplasts!

This connects to phenomenon **p4** - observing which plant parts are green!

hints.content: What do chloroplasts do? What do they need to function?
Chloroplasts perform photosynthesis, which requires light. Which plant part gets no light?

pedagogy.targetFeeling: This is how it works in real life!

questions.stem:
You examine a drop of pond water under a microscope and see dozens of tiny single-celled organisms swimming around.

What must these single-celled organisms have in order to survive?

mcqOptions.text: Only a cell membrane - nothing else is needed
mcqOptions.feedback: All cells need more than just a cell membrane. Think about what controls the cell and stores genetic information.

mcqOptions.text: Cell membrane, cytoplasm, and genetic material (DNA)
mcqOptions.feedback: Correct! ALL cells, even single-celled organisms, must have these three essential structures. The DNA controls the cell, cytoplasm provides a medium for reactions, and the membrane controls what enters and exits.

mcqOptions.text: Cell wall, chloroplasts, and large vacuole
mcqOptions.feedback: These are plant cell structures. Not all single-celled organisms are plant-like - many are more similar to animal cells.

mcqOptions.text: Multiple nuclei to control different functions
mcqOptions.feedback: Single-celled organisms typically have one nucleus or nucleoid region. Multiple nuclei aren't necessary.

questions.solution:
The answer is **B**.

**Essential structures for ALL cells:**

Every living cell, whether single-celled organism or part of a multicellular organism, MUST have:

1. **Cell membrane**: Controls what enters and exits the cell (selective barrier)
2. **Cytoplasm**: Jelly-like substance where chemical reactions occur
3. **Genetic material (DNA)**: Contains instructions for cell survival and reproduction
   - In most cells, DNA is stored in the **nucleus**
   - In bacteria, DNA floats freely in the cytoplasm

**Without these three structures, a cell cannot:**
- Control its internal environment (needs membrane)
- Carry out life processes (needs cytoplasm)
- Reproduce or function properly (needs DNA)

This connects to phenomenon **p10** - observing diverse pond life!

**Additional structures** (like cell walls, chloroplasts, vacuoles) are found in some cells but aren't essential for all life.

hints.content: What three structures do ALL cells have in common, whether plant, animal, or microorganism?
Think about the basic needs: boundary, internal medium, and genetic control. What structures provide these?

pedagogy.targetFeeling: This is how it works in real life!

questions.stem:
A student says: "Cells are solid inside, like a basketball is solid inside."

What is wrong with this statement?

mcqOptions.text: Cells are actually completely empty inside
mcqOptions.feedback: Cells aren't empty - they're filled with cytoplasm and contain many structures.

mcqOptions.text: Cells are filled with air, not solid material
mcqOptions.feedback: This is another misconception! Cells aren't filled with air either.

mcqOptions.text: Cells contain jelly-like cytoplasm with structures floating in it, not solid material
mcqOptions.feedback: Correct! Cells are filled with cytoplasm, which is a gel-like substance. Within the cytoplasm are various structures (nucleus, mitochondria, etc.) - but it's not solid like a ball.

mcqOptions.text: Only plant cells are solid; animal cells are hollow
mcqOptions.feedback: Neither plant nor animal cells are solid or hollow. Both contain cytoplasm.

questions.solution:
The answer is **C**.

**This addresses misconception m2**: "Cells are solid inside (like a ball)"

**The reality - cells are more like a gel balloon:**

| Misconception | Reality |
|---------------|----------|
| Cells are solid throughout | Cells contain **jelly-like cytoplasm** |
| Like a basketball (air-filled ball) | Like a water balloon filled with jelly |
| Uniform material inside | Contains **many different structures** (organelles) |

**What's actually inside a cell:**
- **Cytoplasm**: Gel-like substance made mostly of water with dissolved nutrients, proteins, and salts
- **Nucleus**: Control centre containing DNA
- **Other organelles**: Mitochondria, ribosomes, etc. floating in the cytoplasm
- **Cell membrane**: Flexible outer boundary

Think of cytoplasm like **jelly** - not liquid (flows freely) but not solid (fixed shape). It's a thick, gel-like substance that allows organelles to move slowly within it.

hints.content: Think about what cytoplasm is. Is it a solid, liquid, or something in between?
Cells aren't solid like a rubber ball or empty like a basketball. They're filled with gel-like cytoplasm.

pedagogy.targetFeeling: This is how it works in real life!

questions.stem:
The nucleus is often called the "control centre" of the cell.

Explain what this means and why cells need a control centre. Use an example in your answer.
questions.solution:
The nucleus is called the **control centre** because it contains **DNA** (genetic material) that controls all cell activities.

**What the nucleus controls:**

1. **Which proteins are made**: DNA contains genes - instructions for making specific proteins. The nucleus decides when to activate each gene.

2. **Cell reproduction**: The nucleus controls when and how cells divide to make new cells.

3. **Cell function**: The nucleus determines what type of cell it will be (muscle cell, nerve cell, skin cell, etc.) and what job it will do.

**Why cells need a control centre:**

Without a nucleus:
- Cells wouldn't know which proteins to make
- Chemical reactions would happen randomly without coordination
- Cells couldn't reproduce properly
- The cell would eventually die

**Example:** When you get a cut (like in Question 21), the nucleus in nearby skin cells receives signals and activates genes for cell division. The nucleus "instructs" the cell to divide and produce new skin cells to heal the wound.

Just like a **remote control** manages a TV, the nucleus manages the entire cell's operations!

hints.content: What does the nucleus contain? What information is stored there?
The nucleus contains DNA with instructions. Think about what happens if cells have no instructions to follow.

pedagogy.targetFeeling: This is how it works in real life!

questions.stem:
A scientist removes the nucleus from a cell but keeps the rest of the cell intact.

What will most likely happen to this cell over time?

mcqOptions.text: The cell will function normally since it still has cytoplasm and a cell membrane
mcqOptions.feedback: Without a nucleus, the cell loses its control centre and cannot maintain normal functions for long.

mcqOptions.text: The cell will survive but cannot reproduce
mcqOptions.feedback: While this is partially true initially, the cell will eventually die without the nucleus controlling essential functions.

mcqOptions.text: The cell will gradually lose function and die
mcqOptions.feedback: Correct! Without the nucleus and its DNA, the cell cannot make new proteins to replace damaged ones. Eventually, the cell will deteriorate and die. The nucleus is essential for long-term cell survival.

mcqOptions.text: The cell will grow a new nucleus automatically
mcqOptions.feedback: Cells cannot regenerate a nucleus once it's removed. The nucleus contains unique DNA that cannot be recreated.

questions.solution:
The answer is **C**.

**What happens without a nucleus:**

**Initially (hours to days):**
- Cell membrane still functions
- Cytoplasm still present
- Existing proteins continue working
- Cell appears relatively normal

**Over time (days to weeks):**
- Proteins break down and cannot be replaced (no DNA to make new ones)
- Cell cannot respond to changes or damage
- Essential processes shut down
- Cell deteriorates and dies

**Why the nucleus is essential:**
- Contains **DNA** with instructions for making all proteins
- Controls **cell reproduction**
- Regulates **cell activities** and responses to environment
- Without it, the cell is like a factory without a manager or instruction manual

**Exception:** Red blood cells in mammals actually lose their nucleus as they mature! But they only live about 120 days and cannot reproduce - they're eventually replaced by new cells made in bone marrow (where cells DO have nuclei).

hints.content: What essential information is stored in the nucleus? Can a cell function long-term without it?
The nucleus contains DNA needed to make proteins. Without new proteins being made, what happens as old proteins break down?

pedagogy.targetFeeling: This is how it works in real life!

questions.stem:
Compare these two cell types:

**Cell Type A:** Rectangular shape, rigid, contains chloroplasts
**Cell Type B:** Irregular shape, flexible, no chloroplasts

Which row correctly identifies these cells?

mcqOptions.text: A = Animal cell, B = Plant cell
mcqOptions.feedback: This is reversed. Plant cells have rigid cell walls and chloroplasts, not animal cells.

mcqOptions.text: A = Plant cell, B = Animal cell
mcqOptions.feedback: Correct! Cell A has characteristics of plant cells (rectangular due to cell wall, contains chloroplasts). Cell B has characteristics of animal cells (irregular shape due to flexible membrane only, no chloroplasts).

mcqOptions.text: Both are plant cells from different parts of the plant
mcqOptions.feedback: Cell B lacks chloroplasts and has an irregular shape, which are not typical plant cell characteristics in most plant tissues.

mcqOptions.text: Both are animal cells with different functions
mcqOptions.feedback: Animal cells don't have chloroplasts or rigid rectangular shapes. Cell A is definitely a plant cell.

questions.solution:
The answer is **B**.

**Distinguishing features:**

| Feature | Cell A (Plant) | Cell B (Animal) |
|---------|----------------|------------------|
| **Shape** | Rectangular | Irregular/round |
| **Why?** | Rigid cell wall | Flexible membrane only |
| **Chloroplasts** | Present ✓ | Absent ✗ |
| **Function** | Can photosynthesize | Cannot photosynthesize |
| **Cell wall** | Present ✓ | Absent ✗ |

**Key identification clues:**

1. **Rectangular + rigid** → Must have cell wall → Plant cell
2. **Contains chloroplasts** → Can photosynthesize → Plant cell
3. **Irregular + flexible** → No cell wall → Animal cell
4. **No chloroplasts** → Cannot photosynthesize → Animal cell (or non-green plant cell)

Using these two features together allows you to confidently identify plant vs. animal cells!

hints.content: What gives plant cells their rigid rectangular shape? What structure allows animal cells to be flexible?
Cell walls (plant only) create rigid shapes. Chloroplasts (plant only) allow photosynthesis. Which cell has these?

pedagogy.targetFeeling: This is how it works in real life!

questions.stem:
A student draws this diagram of an animal cell and labels it:

"The cell wall protects the cell. The chloroplasts make energy. The large vacuole stores water."

Identify and correct THREE errors in this student's description of an animal cell.
questions.solution:
**Three errors and corrections:**

**Error 1: "The cell wall protects the cell"**
- **Correction**: Animal cells do NOT have cell walls. They only have a flexible **cell membrane**. Cell walls are found only in plant cells.
- The cell membrane still provides protection and controls what enters/exits, but it's flexible, not rigid.

**Error 2: "The chloroplasts make energy"**
- **Correction**: Animal cells do NOT have chloroplasts. Chloroplasts are found only in plant cells for photosynthesis.
- Animal cells make energy using **mitochondria**, which break down glucose through cellular respiration (not photosynthesis).

**Error 3: "The large vacuole stores water"**
- **Correction**: Animal cells have small vacuoles or sometimes no vacuoles at all. **Large central vacuoles** are a feature of plant cells.
- If animal cells have vacuoles, they are small and temporary, used for storage or waste removal.

**What an animal cell DOES have:**
- Cell membrane (not wall)
- Nucleus
- Cytoplasm
- Small vacuoles (if any)
- Mitochondria (not chloroplasts)
- Other organelles

hints.content: Review the key differences between plant and animal cells. Which structures are unique to each?
Animal cells don't have: cell walls, chloroplasts, or large vacuoles. These are all plant cell features!

pedagogy.targetFeeling: This is how it works in real life!

questions.stem:
You place a plant cell in pure water. Over time, water moves into the cell and the cell swells but doesn't burst.

Which structure prevents the plant cell from bursting?

mcqOptions.text: Cell membrane
mcqOptions.feedback: The cell membrane is flexible and would stretch and burst under too much pressure. It doesn't provide rigid support.

mcqOptions.text: Cell wall
mcqOptions.feedback: Correct! The rigid cell wall provides structural support and prevents the cell from bursting even as it fills with water. This is why plant cells can withstand high internal water pressure.

mcqOptions.text: Nucleus
mcqOptions.feedback: The nucleus controls cell activities but doesn't provide physical protection against bursting.

mcqOptions.text: Vacuole
mcqOptions.feedback: The vacuole stores the water, but it doesn't prevent bursting. In fact, it's the vacuole swelling that creates the pressure!

questions.solution:
The answer is **B**.

**What happens when plant cells absorb water:**

1. Water enters the cell through the cell membrane (by osmosis)
2. Water collects in the **central vacuole**, which swells
3. The vacuole pushes against the **cell membrane**
4. The membrane pushes against the **rigid cell wall**
5. The cell wall resists the pressure and **prevents bursting**
6. The cell becomes **turgid** (firm and swollen)

**Why this matters:**
- Turgid cells keep plants upright and firm
- Without cell walls, plant cells would burst like animal cells do in pure water
- This is why plants wilt when dehydrated - cells lose water pressure and become flaccid (limp)

**Comparison with animal cells:**
- Animal cells in pure water → swell and BURST (no cell wall)
- Plant cells in pure water → swell but stay intact (cell wall protection)

The cell wall is like a **rigid container** that can withstand internal pressure!

hints.content: Which structure in plant cells is rigid and provides structural support?
Think about what makes plant cells different from animal cells. Animal cells burst in pure water - why don't plant cells?

pedagogy.targetFeeling: This is how it works in real life!

questions.stem:
A student examines onion cells under a microscope and sees the cell wall clearly.

The student then stains the cells with iodine and now can see the nucleus.

Why was the nucleus invisible before staining?

mcqOptions.text: The nucleus didn't exist until the stain was added
mcqOptions.feedback: The nucleus was always there! Staining just makes it visible.

mcqOptions.text: The nucleus is transparent and has similar colour to cytoplasm
mcqOptions.feedback: Correct! The nucleus and cytoplasm are both transparent/pale, making them hard to distinguish. Stains bind to certain cell structures, adding colour and making them visible under the microscope.

mcqOptions.text: Onion cells don't normally have nuclei
mcqOptions.feedback: All living plant cells, including onion cells, have nuclei containing DNA.

mcqOptions.text: The microscope wasn't powerful enough
mcqOptions.feedback: The microscope power didn't change. The nucleus is large enough to see - it just lacked contrast before staining.

questions.solution:
The answer is **B**.

**Why staining is important in microscopy:**

**Before staining:**
- Cell structures are mostly transparent or pale
- Nucleus and cytoplasm look similar (both clear/pale)
- Only thick structures like the cell wall are easily visible
- Low **contrast** between structures

**After staining (with iodine):**
- Stain molecules bind to specific structures (like the nucleus)
- These structures become coloured (iodine makes nucleus brown/yellow)
- High **contrast** makes structures clearly visible
- Details become obvious

**Common biological stains:**
- **Iodine**: Stains nucleus and starch (brown/black)
- **Methylene blue**: Stains nucleus (blue)
- **Eosin**: Stains cytoplasm (pink)

**Key principle:** Many cell structures are transparent. Staining adds colour to specific parts, creating **contrast** that makes them visible.

This connects to phenomenon **p6** - observing onion cells under a microscope!

hints.content: Think about what colour most cell structures are naturally. Are they bright and colourful?
Most cell parts are transparent. Stains add colour to make them stand out from their surroundings.

pedagogy.targetFeeling: This is how it works in real life!

questions.stem:
Create a table comparing plant and animal cells. Include at least THREE structures that are:
a) Found in BOTH cell types
b) Found ONLY in plant cells
c) Different between the two cell types
questions.solution:
**Comparison of Plant and Animal Cells:**

| Structure | Plant Cells | Animal Cells | Notes |
|-----------|-------------|--------------|-------|
| **FOUND IN BOTH:** |
| Cell membrane | ✓ Present | ✓ Present | Controls what enters/exits |
| Cytoplasm | ✓ Present | ✓ Present | Jelly-like substance |
| Nucleus | ✓ Present | ✓ Present | Contains DNA, controls cell |
| **FOUND ONLY IN PLANT CELLS:** |
| Cell wall | ✓ Present | ✗ Absent | Rigid, made of cellulose |
| Chloroplasts | ✓ Present (in green parts) | ✗ Absent | Site of photosynthesis |
| Large central vacuole | ✓ Present | ✗ Absent | Stores water, nutrients, waste |
| **DIFFERENT BETWEEN CELLS:** |
| Shape | Regular, rectangular | Irregular, varied |
| Vacuoles | Large central vacuole | Small or absent |
| Rigidity | Rigid (due to cell wall) | Flexible (membrane only) |

**Summary:**
- **Similarities**: Both have cell membrane, cytoplasm, and nucleus (basic structures)
- **Plant-specific**: Cell wall, chloroplasts, large vacuole (support + energy production)
- **Key differences**: Plant cells are structured for support and photosynthesis; animal cells are flexible

hints.content: Start with structures all cells must have. Then think about what makes plant cells unique.
Both cells: membrane, cytoplasm, nucleus. Plant only: wall, chloroplasts, large vacuole.

pedagogy.targetFeeling: This is how it works in real life!

questions.stem:
A biologist is studying different organisms under a microscope. She observes:

**Organism A:** Single-celled, has a cell wall and chloroplast
**Organism B:** Single-celled, has a cell membrane but no cell wall or chloroplast
**Organism C:** Multi-celled, cells have cell walls and large vacuoles

Which statement is most accurate?

mcqOptions.text: All three are animals because they're alive
mcqOptions.feedback: Cell walls and chloroplasts are plant characteristics, not animal. Organism structure tells us about its classification.

mcqOptions.text: A and C are plant-like; B is animal-like
mcqOptions.feedback: Correct! Organisms A and C have plant cell characteristics (cell wall, and A has chloroplasts). Organism B lacks these structures, making it more animal-like.

mcqOptions.text: Only C is a plant because it's multi-celled
mcqOptions.feedback: Single-celled organisms can also have plant-like characteristics (cell wall, chloroplasts). Being multi-celled isn't the only criterion.

mcqOptions.text: All three are bacteria because they're under a microscope
mcqOptions.feedback: Being microscopic doesn't make something bacteria. The presence of chloroplasts and nucleus indicates more complex organisms.

questions.solution:
The answer is **B**.

**Analyzing each organism:**

**Organism A (Plant-like):**
- Cell wall → Plant characteristic
- Chloroplast → Can photosynthesize
- Single-celled → Likely an algae (like Euglena)

**Organism B (Animal-like):**
- Cell membrane but no cell wall → Animal characteristic
- No chloroplast → Cannot photosynthesize (must consume food)
- Single-celled → Likely a protozoan (like Amoeba)

**Organism C (Plant):**
- Cell walls → Plant characteristic
- Large vacuoles → Plant characteristic
- Multi-celled → Likely a plant tissue sample

**Key principle:** 
Cell structure tells us about organism type:
- Cell wall + chloroplasts = Plant or plant-like
- Membrane only, no chloroplasts = Animal or animal-like

This connects to phenomenon **p10** - pond water contains diverse microscopic life!

hints.content: What structures are unique to plant cells? Which organisms have these structures?
Cell walls and chloroplasts indicate plant-like organisms. Which organisms have these?

pedagogy.targetFeeling: This is how it works in real life!

questions.stem:
The cell membrane is described as "selectively permeable."

What does this mean?

mcqOptions.text: The membrane allows all substances to pass through freely
mcqOptions.feedback: If all substances could pass freely, cells couldn't control their internal environment. The membrane is selective.

mcqOptions.text: The membrane blocks all substances from entering or leaving
mcqOptions.feedback: If nothing could pass through, cells couldn't get nutrients or remove waste. Some substances must pass through.

mcqOptions.text: The membrane allows some substances through but blocks others
mcqOptions.feedback: Correct! 'Selectively permeable' means the membrane chooses what can pass through. Small molecules like water and oxygen can pass; large molecules and harmful substances are blocked.

mcqOptions.text: The membrane only exists in plant cells
mcqOptions.feedback: All cells (plant and animal) have cell membranes. This is a universal cell structure.

questions.solution:
The answer is **C**.

**Selectively permeable membrane:**

**What it means:**
- The cell membrane acts like a **selective gatekeeper**
- Some substances can pass through, others cannot
- This allows cells to **control their internal environment**

**What CAN pass through:**
- Small molecules: water (H₂O), oxygen (O₂), carbon dioxide (CO₂)
- Some nutrients (depending on size and properties)

**What CANNOT easily pass through:**
- Large molecules (proteins, starch)
- Charged particles (ions) without special channels
- Harmful substances

**Why this is important:**

| If membrane was... | Result |
|-------------------|--------|
| Completely permeable | Cell loses control; harmful substances enter freely |
| Completely impermeable | Cell starves; waste builds up; cell dies |
| **Selectively permeable** | **Cell maintains balance; gets nutrients; removes waste** |

Think of it like a **security checkpoint** - only authorized substances get through!

hints.content: What does 'selective' mean? What does 'permeable' mean? Put them together.
The membrane needs to let nutrients in and waste out, but keep harmful things out. How would it do this?

pedagogy.targetFeeling: This is how it works in real life!

questions.stem:
Explain why plant cells need BOTH a cell membrane AND a cell wall.

Why isn't just one of these structures sufficient?
questions.solution:
Plant cells need BOTH structures because they serve **different functions**:

**Cell Membrane (all cells have this):**
- **Function**: Controls what enters and exits the cell
- **Property**: Selectively permeable - lets some molecules through, blocks others
- **Flexibility**: Flexible and can change shape slightly
- **Location**: Just inside the cell wall in plant cells
- **Essential for**: Nutrient uptake, waste removal, communication

**Cell Wall (plant cells only):**
- **Function**: Provides structural support and protection
- **Property**: Rigid and strong (made of cellulose)
- **Flexibility**: Does NOT control what passes through - fully permeable to small molecules
- **Location**: Outer layer of plant cell
- **Essential for**: Shape maintenance, preventing bursting, plant structural support

**Why BOTH are needed:**

1. **Cell wall alone** → Cannot control what enters/exits (it's permeable to everything small)
2. **Cell membrane alone** → Cell would be flexible like animal cells; plant would collapse without rigid support
3. **Both together** → Protection + control + structural support

**Analogy**: The cell wall is like a house's walls (structure), while the cell membrane is like the door (controls entry/exit). You need both!

hints.content: Think about what each structure does. Do they have the same function or different functions?
The membrane controls movement in/out. The wall provides rigid structure. Both are necessary!

pedagogy.targetFeeling: This is how it works in real life!

questions.stem:
A student observes a leaf cell and a root cell from the same plant under a microscope.

Which observation would the student most likely make?

mcqOptions.text: The leaf cell has chloroplasts; the root cell does not
mcqOptions.feedback: Correct! Leaf cells are exposed to sunlight and contain chloroplasts for photosynthesis. Root cells are underground with no light access, so they don't have chloroplasts. This shows not all plant cells are identical!

mcqOptions.text: The leaf cell has a cell wall; the root cell does not
mcqOptions.feedback: Both are plant cells, so both have cell walls. The cell wall is a defining feature of all plant cells.

mcqOptions.text: The leaf cell has a nucleus; the root cell does not
mcqOptions.feedback: All living plant cells have nuclei containing DNA. Both leaf and root cells need genetic control.

mcqOptions.text: The cells would look identical in every way
mcqOptions.feedback: While both are plant cells with similar basic structures, they're specialized for different functions and have some differences.

questions.solution:
The answer is **A**.

**Comparing leaf cells vs. root cells:**

| Structure | Leaf Cell | Root Cell | Why Different? |
|-----------|-----------|-----------|----------------|
| Cell wall | ✓ Present | ✓ Present | Both are plant cells |
| Cell membrane | ✓ Present | ✓ Present | All cells need this |
| Nucleus | ✓ Present | ✓ Present | All cells need DNA |
| Cytoplasm | ✓ Present | ✓ Present | All cells need this |
| Large vacuole | ✓ Present | ✓ Present | Both are plant cells |
| **Chloroplasts** | **✓ Present** | **✗ Absent** | **Only needed where there's light!** |

**Key insight:**
Not all plant cells are the same! Cells are **specialized** for their location and function:
- **Leaf cells**: Exposed to sunlight → Have chloroplasts → Can photosynthesize → Appear green
- **Root cells**: Underground, no light → No chloroplasts → Cannot photosynthesize → Appear white/pale

This reinforces that **chloroplasts are only found where photosynthesis can occur** (misconception m5)!

hints.content: Think about where each cell type is located in the plant. What resource is available in one location but not the other?
Leaves get sunlight; roots don't. Which cell structure is only useful when there's light?

pedagogy.targetFeeling: This is how it works in real life!

questions.stem:
A student says: "I think cells are filled with air, like a balloon. That's why they're so light."

Using your knowledge of cell structure, explain why this statement is incorrect. What is actually inside cells?
questions.solution:
**This statement is incorrect.** This addresses misconception **m3**: "Cells are filled with air."

**What's actually inside cells:**

Cells are NOT filled with air. They are filled with **cytoplasm**, which is:

**Composition of cytoplasm:**
- Mostly **water** (about 70-80%)
- Dissolved **salts and minerals**
- **Proteins and enzymes** (do the cell's work)
- **Nutrients** (sugars, amino acids)
- **Organic molecules** needed for cell function

**Physical properties:**
- Gel-like or jelly-like consistency
- NOT a gas (air)
- NOT empty space
- Dense enough to hold organelles in place

**Why cells seem light:**
Cells ARE light, but not because they're filled with air! They're light because:
1. They're mostly water (which is relatively light)
2. They're extremely **small** (microscopic)
3. Individual molecules are tiny

**Evidence cells aren't air-filled:**
- Cells sink in water (air-filled things float)
- You can see structures floating in cytoplasm under a microscope
- Cells maintain shape even without rigid walls (in animals)

**Better analogy:** A cell is like a **water balloon filled with jelly**, not an air balloon!

hints.content: What is cytoplasm? What is it made of?
Cells are filled with cytoplasm, which is mostly water with dissolved substances - not air!

pedagogy.targetFeeling: This is how it works in real life!

questions.stem:
You're examining cells from different parts of a plant:

**Sample 1:** Green leaf cells with many chloroplasts
**Sample 2:** White root cells with no chloroplasts
**Sample 3:** Stem cells with a few chloroplasts

What explains the different numbers of chloroplasts in these cells?

mcqOptions.text: All plant cells should have the same number of chloroplasts
mcqOptions.feedback: Plant cells are specialized for different functions. Chloroplast number varies based on the cell's location and role.

mcqOptions.text: Cells produce chloroplasts based on light exposure
mcqOptions.feedback: Correct! Cells exposed to more light develop more chloroplasts for photosynthesis. Leaves get most light (many chloroplasts), roots get none (no chloroplasts), stems get some (few chloroplasts).

mcqOptions.text: Older cells lose their chloroplasts over time
mcqOptions.feedback: Age isn't the factor here. Root cells never have chloroplasts because they're always underground, regardless of age.

mcqOptions.text: Chloroplasts randomly appear and disappear in cells
mcqOptions.feedback: Chloroplast presence is not random - it's determined by the cell's location and function (mainly light exposure).

questions.solution:
The answer is **B**.

**Why chloroplast numbers vary:**

| Plant Part | Light Exposure | Chloroplast Number | Purpose |
|------------|----------------|--------------------|---------|
| **Leaves** | High (direct sunlight) | Many (densely packed) | Maximum photosynthesis |
| **Stems** | Moderate (some exposure) | Few (scattered) | Some photosynthesis + support |
| **Roots** | None (underground) | Zero | No photosynthesis; absorption only |

**Key principle: Structure follows function**
- Cells develop structures they need for their specific job
- Light exposure determines whether chloroplasts are useful
- **More light = more chloroplasts = more photosynthesis**

**This explains:**
- Why leaves are the main photosynthetic organs (most chloroplasts)
- Why roots are white/pale (no chloroplasts)
- Why green stems can photosynthesize but aren't as efficient as leaves

**Real-world observation:** If you grow a plant in darkness, even leaf cells will have fewer, paler chloroplasts - demonstrating the relationship between light and chloroplast development!

hints.content: What do chloroplasts do? What do they need to function?
Chloroplasts need light for photosynthesis. Where does each plant part experience different amounts of light?

pedagogy.targetFeeling: This is how it works in real life!

questions.stem:
You observe these three scenarios:

1. A cut on your skin healing over several days
2. Leaves appearing green in sunlight
3. Plant stems standing upright even without bones

Choose ONE scenario and explain how cell structures make this possible. Identify at least TWO specific cell structures in your answer.
questions.solution:
**Any ONE of the following explanations is acceptable:**

---

**Scenario 1: Skin healing (Phenomenon p1)**

Cell structures involved:

1. **Nucleus**: Contains DNA with instructions for cell division. When skin is damaged, the nucleus activates genes that trigger cell division to produce new skin cells.

2. **Cell membrane**: Controls what enters and exits cells. During healing, the membrane allows nutrients and growth factors to enter cells, providing materials needed for growth and repair.

How it works: The nucleus detects the injury signal and initiates cell division. New daughter cells are produced with identical DNA. These cells migrate to fill the gap, eventually closing the wound.

---

**Scenario 2: Leaves appearing green (Phenomenon p4)**

Cell structures involved:

1. **Chloroplasts**: Contain chlorophyll (green pigment) that absorbs sunlight for photosynthesis. When light hits chloroplasts, the chlorophyll reflects green wavelengths, making leaves appear green.

2. **Cell wall**: The transparent cell wall in leaf cells allows light to pass through to reach the chloroplasts inside.

How it works: Light passes through the transparent cell wall and reaches chloroplasts. Chlorophyll absorbs red and blue light but reflects green, making the leaf appear green to our eyes.

---

**Scenario 3: Plant stems standing upright**

Cell structures involved:

1. **Cell wall**: Rigid structure made of cellulose provides strength and prevents cells from collapsing under their own weight.

2. **Large central vacuole**: When filled with water, creates internal pressure (turgor pressure) that pushes against the cell wall, making cells rigid and firm.

How it works: Water in the vacuole creates pressure, pushing the cell membrane against the cell wall. The rigid cell wall resists this pressure. Millions of turgid (firm) cells stacked together create a strong, upright structure - no bones needed!

hints.content: Pick the scenario you understand best. Think about which cell structures are directly involved.
Scenario 1: nucleus and membrane. Scenario 2: chloroplasts and cell wall. Scenario 3: cell wall and vacuole.

pedagogy.targetFeeling: This is how it works in real life!

questions.stem: A student says: 'The nucleus is the brain of the cell because it thinks and makes decisions.' What is wrong with this statement?

mcqOptions.text: The nucleus doesn't think - it stores DNA and controls cell activities through chemical instructions
mcqOptions.feedback: Correct! The nucleus doesn't 'think' or have consciousness. It controls the cell by storing genetic information (DNA) and sending chemical instructions (RNA) to other organelles. It's a control center, not a brain that thinks.

mcqOptions.text: The nucleus is actually the stomach of the cell, not the brain
mcqOptions.feedback: The nucleus isn't like a stomach either - analogies to body parts can be misleading. The nucleus is a control center that stores genetic information and coordinates cell activities.

mcqOptions.text: Nothing is wrong - the nucleus does think like a brain
mcqOptions.feedback: The nucleus cannot think. It's a compartment containing DNA that controls cell functions through chemical signals, not through thought or consciousness.

mcqOptions.text: The cell membrane is the brain, not the nucleus
mcqOptions.feedback: Neither the nucleus nor the cell membrane 'think.' The cell membrane controls what enters and exits the cell, while the nucleus stores genetic information. Neither has consciousness.

questions.solution:
The answer is **the nucleus doesn't think - it stores DNA and controls cell activities through chemical instructions**.

This addresses a **common misconception** about the nucleus:
